title: Feature Request: PROXY support for RDP connections
author: lars18th
body_snippet:
Hi,

I'm using mRemote/mRemoteNG for several years. However, for RDP connections I continue using the 2X/Parallels Client. Why? Because it has a "must have" option for RDP connections: support for PROXY.

Let me to explain:

- In the configuration of the RDP connection, you have a new tab with these values:

```
[ ] Use proxy server
  ( ) SOCKS4
  ( ) SOCKS4A
  ( ) SOCKS5
  ( ) HTTP 1.1
  Proxy Host:
  Port:

Proxy Authentication ...
```

This is relevant when you use one SSH...

iterations.description: Legitimate feature request for RDP proxy support - a common enterprise need that mRemoteNG currently lacks, and the reporter correctly pointed out this cannot be 'retested' since the feature does not exist yet

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet:
If I'm understanding correctly, this is already possible using PuTTY to set up a SOCKS4 tunnel. Admittedly, this requires a bit more work to setup and use on a daily basis.

Making this a more integrated feature of RDP connections would be possible but a bit more difficult using PuTTY directly. It is suggested that we complete #181 first and build this feature with SSH.Net.

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi @sparerd ,

I feel you misunderstood my proposal. Let me to explain more:

- I'm **not** suggesting to connect with RDP using SSH.
- I'm suggesting that the TCP connection to an RDP server is done **using a PROXY**.
- I'm suggesting that the proxy support includes **SOCKS** and HTTP-CONNECT protocols.

My goal (and not the only use of the proxy support) is:

1) I connect to one SSH server in the same network as the RDP server is running.
2) In this SSH connection I enable one "Dyna...

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet:
Ok, on a second pass I see the issue you're bringing up. The library we use for RDP (mstsclib) doesn't natively support any proxy type besides RD Gateway.

We will need to find a library that provides SOCKS/HTTP proxy support. If you know of a good library let us know and we can look into it.

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi,

In a second pass...

You don't need at all a library for RDP with proxy support (this doesn't exist!).
You need to use a library for PROXY connection, or directly implement it in the code. Let me explain how to:

- If you use regular RDP connection, use the mstsclib as normal.
- If you use proxied RDP connection, do:
  - Open the TCP connection using the proxy with these parameters:
     - IP destination: address of the proxy
     - PORT destination: port of the proxy
     - Rem...

comments.author: JarRoDk
comments.snippet:
I also very often use dynamic tunnel in putty. For example for Firefox to use socks connections. 
The biggest advantage in dynamic tunneling is that i don't need specify target connection. 
As you mentioned RDP don't have by default this feature so it is hard to force to use socks especially on windows. I searched software which will put on RDP rule that every connection from mstsc.exe should go throw socks or if software discovery flow to specific network. ProxyCap, Proxyfier, MobaXterm can d...

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi @JarRoDk ,

I feel I don't explain well. Let me try another time:

- The RDP protocol use by default TCP (only in recent versions of the protocol the UDP transport is also optionally accepted).
- With **ANY** service that uses TCP is possible to use TCP tunnels.
- In order to tunnel one RDP connection over a TCP connection you need to use as target the tunnel address:port, instead of the remote address:port.

So, for tunneling one RDP connection over a SOCKS proxy, the client only nee...

comments.author: JarRoDk
comments.snippet:
Yes, I understand how simple static tunnel works and for one target it is very easy and handy (and this same for 3306 port), for example:
i can create tunnel in putty 2022:target:22 for one target and then ssh to localhost:2022

But with dynamic tunnel it is even better because i don't need to specify targets i can force my putty client to use sock proxy
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1716484/26442545/3ccc8b7a-4135-11e7-8a15-d7e448ef59f0.png)


![image](https://cloud....

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
HI @JarRoDk .

> If mstc.exe can use socks proxing like other mature software ; ] it would be any problems.

My request is because mstc.exe don't have support for PROXY.

However, it's very simple to add support for it (and other tools) inside mRemoteNG:
- The UI needs to add the space for specify the proxy server.
- The internal code requires to have the function to stablish the tunnel before run the tool (mstc.exe).
- After stablish the tunnel, just do run the tool (mstc.exe) with the...

comments.author: dgcom
comments.snippet:
I haven't tried this in mRemoteNG, but I use it elsewhere - find compiled version of connect.c - this small program can listen on a socket and send TCP stream over proxy.
I use it to proxy RDP connections via SSH in another app similar to mRemoteNG - I first establish SSH connection via putty with dynamic port forward which is socks proxy and then use connect.exe to forward local port to destination RDP server.
This works fine, without much extra work once setup.
But it would be great if mRem...

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
> I use it to proxy RDP connections via SSH in another app similar to mRemoteNG

Hi dgcom,

Yes, you can do it manually. And you have a lot of options. For example, a simple SSH tunnel is a very simple way. However, with a large list of RDP servers and with one Proxy, it will be more powerfull to have this functionality implemented.

I hope that soon the developers of the mRemoteNG will agree with the inclusion of the Proxy support. :smile:

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet: I agree this would be a great feature to have. However, I am not sure when I will have the time to implement it. We will likely need someone to submit a PR to get it done in any reasonable amount of time.

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi,

In my opinion this function is a must have!
Why?

1. Any RDP connection can work over a TCP tunnel. So it doesn't disturbs the client or the server.
2. A lot of IT professionals use remote SSH connections to accesing to secure _networks_, instead of a complex VPN solutions. In these environments a RDP client with socks proxy client support is a _huge_ advantage.
3. Add support for tunneled conections is quite easy when including some proxy client library. The algoritm is then trivial...

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet:
In short, we don't have enough developer time to do this right now. It would be great to have this, but there are many other significant features that are ahead of this one. (HiDPI, credential manager, hotkeys, just to name a few). And that's not even taking into consideration that all feature work is on hold until v1.76 is released. Bug fixes are getting priority.

We need some more developers :(

Thank you for your efffort!

comments.author: reillychase
comments.snippet: Proxy support for RDP would be awesome!

comments.author: st-schuler
comments.snippet:
I'm going to implement this now. Here's my plan:

The user should be able to define one or more SSH gateways. This is implemented as a new "protocol", i.e. an SSH gateway can then be configured like a normal connection. The following parameters are defined:
- name
- description
- hostname
- port
- username
- password
	
Each connection/folder now has a new property which can be used to select one of the previously defined SSH gateways via dropdown box. If the connection is activated, th...

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi @st-schuler ,

> I'm going to implement this now.

Great to hear it!

However, please **don't forget the pure PROXY support!** Your idea is about use SSH tunnels, and it's amazing. But, _PROXY_ support is a different (but complementary) functionality. For example, with an HTTP proxy you use a tunnel over a TCP connection with the HTTP CONNECT command. With a SOCKS proxy you ask to the server for a TCP tunnel.

So, I recommend not only to add support for "SSH gateways" but too for "HTT...

comments.author: st-schuler
comments.snippet:
SSH keys are also supported.
Currently I will only implement ssh-tunnel/gateway. Proxy is then another thing, but shouldn't be that difficult.

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi @st-schuler ,

> Currently I will only implement ssh-tunnel/gateway. Proxy is then another thing, but shouldn't be that difficult

Sorry, but my original request (see the title of _this_ issue) is about the PROXY support. The SSH-TUNNEL/GATEWAY is another different functionality. I agree with it, however it's more complex to implement. And in the other hand, less usefull... why? You can do the tunnel manually (you only need to configure your SSH client), but what about the PROXY support? ...

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi,

Is anyone working on the implementation of this?

Please note that at time the VNC client *has* support for HTTP and SOCKS proxies.
See: https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/blob/05c96da98f475e6152418632d8259e34d73a51ee/mRemoteV1/Connection/Protocol/VNC/VNCEnum.cs#L52
My request is only to implement the *same* support for the RDP client!
And this seems to be quite easy as the VNC proxy code can be reused. The VNC connection is a TCP socket, so the proxy is transparent. And the RDP ...

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet:
Actually you've uncovered something pretty interesting here. VNC actually doesn't have any proxy support in the app. The proxy settings for VNC connections aren't hooked up to anything except serializers/deserializers. They don't actually *do* anything at the moment. I'm not even sure why those properties exist, except maybe the implementation just wasn't completed.

This still means the property serialization/deserialization work is mostly done, but we still need to create the actual proxy im...

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Oh, sorry @sparerd !

In any case, I suggest to include (at some time) an abstract base "proxy" connection for all procotols that use TCP sockets.

You agree?

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet: Absolutely. Any connection type that supports TCP should also be usable with the TCP proxy (regardless of implementation details).

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi,

I want to comment what I'm doing for the last years:

- To connect to remote servers, I stablish an SSH connection with one server connected to the Internet. Then inside the SSH connection I open a Socks4 forwarding proxy. And using this socks proxy I connect to any of the servers in that location.

I feel a lot of users use this technique: simple and secure. I hate to waste my time with VPNs or bastion servers for specific services. But, it requires that the CLIENT supports connectin...

comments.author: drehelis
comments.snippet:
I was able to achieve this, using [proxychains-windows](https://github.com/shunf4/proxychains-windows) (windows port of [proxychains)](https://github.com/haad/proxychains).
You can control which IP range not to proxy and it's possible to configure advanced routing rules.

_Yes_, this is not the perfect solution as this is a wrapper for `mRemoteNG` but it does the trick.

Wrapping this in a small PS script should be enough to get you started.
```
$WorkDir = "C:\Users\autogun\Downloads\prox...

comments.author: lars18th
comments.snippet:
Hi,

To be clear:

1. RDP connections, like _any_ other TCP connection can be _tunneled_. That's not the question.
2. SSH can provide tunnels. That's not the question.
3. We can use _any_ RDP client over a SSH connection using tunnels. Tht's not the question.
4. _ANY_ TCP connection can be done over a SOCKS4 or HTTP proxy (in this case with CONNECT support). And this is the question to support inside mRemoteNG.

Futhermore, this TCP PROXY support inside mRemoteNG could be used for any t...

Ok it works, but it's a bit overhead. Like for your web browser, a simple proxy config by r...

comments.author: merarischroeder
comments.snippet:
@lars18th Good suggestion. This can easily be accomplished within mRemoteNG and the System.Net.Sockets namespace.

For HTTP Proxy of RDP:

- User configures: RDP details - my-server.example.net (and maybe more)
- User configures: RDP proxy - HTTP-Proxy:10.0.0.5
- When the connection is made, mRemoteNG creates an arbitrary loopback TCP listener. Eg. 127.60.98.4:3389
- mRemoteNG starts up mstsc with 127.60.98.4:3389
- When a client connects to that listener, mRemoteNG connects to the HTTP-...

I hope you will complete this library soon, and someone will incorporate it.
Thank you!

comments.author: merarischroeder
comments.snippet: This can be done without my library, the System.Net.Sockets namespace has got everything needed. I always build with what's available - my library isn't available yet, so if anyone is keen, it will probably take 20-40 hours (possibly shorter) to complete the specification in my [comment above](https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues/420#issuecomment-968200332) using direct normal C#. I don't have the time at the moment, I'm busy building a library.

notes:
AI triage: Legitimate feature request for RDP proxy support - a common enterprise need that mRemoteNG currently lacks, and the reporter correctly pointed out this cannot be 'retested' since the feature does not exist yet
Approach: Add proxy configuration fields (proxy type, host, port, credentials) to ConnectionInfo and expose them in the RDP connection settings UI, then pass proxy settings to the RDP ActiveX control via IMsRdpClientAdvancedSettings properties (ProxyType, ProxyHost, ProxyPort) when establishing connections
